utterances: I know that it's a gentler record than the ones I've made in the past, and I know that, personally, I'm not trying so hard to prove that I know about music in different genres.
And I don't think it's because I've proved it either.
It's just because I just - I've given up.
I don't care about trying to show off.
And I don't care about presuming that there's such a thing as knowing a lot about music.
It's unbelievable how much more there is to explore and discover.

(Singing) 'Cause when love shows its face, the rest just falls into place.
Devendra Banhart's new album, ""Ape In Pink Marble,"" is out now.

(Singing) All of the pain that followed the lady in waiting.
Google has been working hard to bring its ultra-high-speed Internet to cities across the country, but that service, Google Fiber, might have hit a snag in Louisville, Ky.
AT&T has filed a federal lawsuit against the city after local lawmakers streamlined the installation process for Fiber Internet providers.
That lawsuit could have big implications for Google Fiber beyond Kentucky.
Jake Ryan from member station WFPL reports.
Matt Embry cranes his neck as he stands just off a busy highway in Louisville.
So we're looking at a typical telephone pole.
It's a little bit worn and aged, but when you look up the pole, the first thing that you will see attached to it is part of AT&T's network infrastructure.
Embry is the president of the local Communications Workers of America union.
He says access to these poles is the root of the lawsuit filed by AT&T of Kentucky.
The company alleges the Louisville Metro City Council overstepped its jurisdiction when it approved a policy to streamline high-speed Internet installation.
The issue - allowing a contractor for one company to move utility cables of a competitor.
Embry says that breaches the union contract with AT&T.
This work has been done by bargain employees for a very long time, and we have negotiated contract after contract for decades to have that exclusivity for CWA workers to do that.
Industry watchers say the suit is more than just protecting the rights of union workers.
Jason Hiner is a chief global editor of TechRepublic, an online trade publication.
He notes AT&T also wants to bring high-speed Internet to Louisville.
The longer that they can delay this for Google, the faster they can get their product to market, and so that behooves them.
The suit isn't against Google Fiber.
It targets the city of Louisville, so any company's installation could be delayed here.
Hiner says the suit has far-reaching implications for Google, which wants to bring gigabit speed Internet across the U.S.

Louisville is much more like most of the top 10 cities in America like San Francisco and New York where the infrastructure's owned by these different entities and Google has to negotiate a way, you know, with the city or these other entities to get the right-of-way, essentially.
Hiner says other cities will likely fight Google Fiber.
It's already been done in Tempe, Ariz., and Austin, Texas.
A major delay in Louisville could slow Google Fiber's future expansion.
It's a really important test case.
You know, for the future of Internet and the U.S., it has pretty huge implications.
Ted Smith is the city of Louisville's chief innovation officer.
He knows other regions are watching closely.
Everybody's in a slightly different position or a situation, but there are a lot of commonalities, and there are a lot of places in the country where pole attachment is a real factor.
But the bulk of your business, though, is selling stuff that you've processed there at the plant?
Mr.
Obama often talks about these plants as engines for a new, clean-energy economy.
But the plants have been slow to jump-start the nation's sputtering job market, as NPR's Scott Horsley reports.
(SOUNDBITE OF CONSTRUCTION MACHINES)
Batteries built here in Holland will one day power the Chevy Volt from General Motors, as well as a new electric version of the Ford Focus.
Civic leaders who lobbied for the plant think the batteries will also give a jolt to the surrounding community.
Now, we've taken our lumps in this economy.

And, you know, to see all the people that are working out there on the construction site today, to consider how many people are going to be, you know, parking their cars in the parking lot to work there here in the next 18 months, I mean, it's something.
It's just a great shot in the arm for our community.
Randy Thelen heads an economic development company in the area called Lakeshore Advantage.
Over breakfast in a downtown restaurant, he told me that Holland will actually be home to two advanced battery plants.
Together, they receive some $450 million in grants from the federal government.
The stimulus certainly has done its job here in Holland, Michigan.
We've got, you know, great opportunities in front of us, and many of which have been driven by the stimulus package.
But that's created some mixed feelings here in western Michigan.
This is Republican country, where John McCain outpolled Barack Obama two years ago with 61 percent of the vote.
The Holland area also has an active Tea Party movement.
I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America.
Jim Chiodo, who chaired the meeting, says he has nothing against the jobs the new battery plant will eventually provide.
But he doesn't believe it's the government's role to be picking winners and losers, or to be helping either one.
For every winner, there's 10 losers.
And it's really, really hard to take a position that's against your hometown.
I'm not against my hometown.
I love Holland.
I've been here 25 years.
It's a great town.
But it's going to hurt towns like Holland when this gravy train gets turned off.

Michigan's unemployment rate is the second highest in the country, and Angie Barksdale of the employment training program Michigan Works says the pain reaches across the state, from Detroit to Lake Michigan.

I think many people don't realize that even the West Side has been hit just as hard as the East Side, and especially when you look at the stats for the city of Holland particular, there are pockets that are even hungrier.
The battery plant breaking ground today will eventually employ about 400 people.
But most of those jobs are at least 18 months away.
And Cedric Jones, who recently lost a manufacturing job, can't wait that long.
Actually, I can't even wait 18 hours, for real.
I need a job, like, right now because I've got to pay rent.
I don't know what the president's going to do about it, but, you know, whatever he can, you know, because actually, I do need a stimulus package.
(SOUNDBITE OF LAUGHTER)
That sounds pretty good to Holland's economic development leader Randy Thelen.
For the country and for communities like Holland, it is important to take the long-term view on this.
You know, Rome wasn't built in a day, and the electric vehicle industry won't be built in a day.
But it has great potential.
It has great opportunity.
We're going to be at the forefront of that here in Holland, Michigan, and we're thrilled to be - to have that position.
Scott Horsley, NPR News, Holland, Michigan.
Its MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Im Steve Inskeep.
And Im Renee Montagne.
The authorities in Chile are struggling today to get food, water and medical supplies to southern and coastal parts of the country.
Those are the regions hit hardest by Saturdays earthquake, an earthquake that killed more than 700 people and left hundreds of thousands without homes.
One of the worst hit cities is Concepcion, and reporter Annie Murphy is there.
Hello, good morning.
Good morning.
Is there any sign of emergency supplies reaching the city?
So far I havent seen any.
I have heard some rumors of several outlying neighborhoods having some supplies being delivered by their neighborhood organizations.
But from what I have seen tonight, there still arent any supplies here.
And were hearing reports of widespread looting.
I mean, people clearly in need there, but also looting of stores for other things.
Is that what you have seen?
During the day yesterday I did see quite a bit of looting.
It hit a point in the afternoon where it got pretty intense.
They burned the supermarket and the fire is still going on right now.
Its a very large supermarket.
In terms of over the night, I havent seen any looting during the night.
Ive seen a lot of people out waiting to protect their houses or their businesses from potential looting, but I havent actually seen any looting tonight.
And you said burned a supermarket.
What, cleared it out of the food and then burned it?
I mean, that doesnt in some sense make sense.
Yeah, (unintelligible) either.
I assume that people are just in poor enough spirits at this point that they are just, you know, theyre not just looking to satisfy their needs, they're probably looking to make a statement as well.
What about organized attempts to dig people out of collapsed buildings?
Is that happening?
Yeah, I mean, there is not the same number of - but a lot of people are not getting, you know, just whole city is leveled.
Here what happened is, its pretty intermittent.
A lot of houses have significant damage, but very few buildings have entirely collapsed.
A lot of them are businesses where there wasnt anyone inside.
There are several larger buildings and one of them is a 15-storey apartment building that collapsed.
Theres an ongoing effort (unintelligible) that building.
